g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
Models of the innovation process, its drivers and incentives provide a tool for technology assessment
. The distinction between stages of innovation process allows
to assess technology readiness (Section 16.2.1). Qualitative and quantitative analysis of main elements
In addition, general purpose technologies can play a role
In the context of mitigation pathways, the feasibil
ity of any emission reduction targets depends on the
ability to promote innovation in low
carbon technologies, as opposed to any other technology.
For this reason, the section reviews the literature of the levers influencing the
n IAMs, hence permitting more precise modelling of
In addition to technological innovation, other innovation approaches are relevant in the context of
climate mitigation and more broadly sustainable development
. Grassroots innovations are products, services and
processes developed to address specific local challenges and opportunities, a
up solutions responding to local situations, interests and values.
The innovation cycle is commonly thought of as having three distinct innovation phases on the path
between basic research and commercial applicati
. Each of these phases differs with respect to the kind of
activity carried out, the type of actors involved and their role, financing needs and the associated risks
and uncertainties. All phases involve a process of trial and error, and failure is common;
innovation that successfully reaches the deployment phase is small. The path occurring between basic
is not linear (see also Section 16.3); it
often requires a long time and is
backwards in the innovation cycle, rather than move forward
from each stage to the next one in the innovati
on cycle requires overcoming “valleys of deaths”
. Over time, new and improved technologies are discovered;
this often makes the dominant technology obsolete
Table 16.2 summarizes the different innovation stages and main funding actors, and maps phases into
the technology readiness levels (TRLs) discussed in Section 16.
